page.title: 08EDINBANE - PEAT CUTTING
page.content: Many families rent part of a peat bog to cut for fuel. The most difficult job is turfing because we have to cut through the heather roots to expose the peat. Using a spade we cut the first row of peats. As they fall down, they are caught and thrown to the top of the bog where they are spread out to begin drying. For lower rows we use a peat-iron. When the peats have dried a bit we stand four on end to form a pyramid and lay a fifth on top. This allows the wind to dry them thoroughly. Once the peats are dry, we take them home in a tractor-drawn trailer. The big stacks are carefully built so that rain cannot get in to spoil the peats. This year some peat has been cut by machine and is sold in sacks.
